spoken_words: Absolutely not! No quack sawbones is going to apply his leeches to me! As long as there's an ounce of strength left in me, I...
Smithers, don't feel so bad. After all, that kidney you donated to me really hit the spot.
Smithers, I'm not going to make it. I want to dictate... my epitaph.
"O Tyrant Hear His Mighty Name And QUAKE!!" Smithers, I'm back!
Oh, top o' the mornin' to ye! Why, look who's here! It's good old... you!
Oh, hey, there, Mr... Brown Shoes! How about that local sports team? Hm?
Smithers, I'm back in the pink! Full of pith and vinegar!
You know, it's funny, Smithers. I tried every tincture and poultice and tonic and patent medicine there is. And all I really needed was the blood of a young boy. By the way, what was the lad's name?
Well, the Simpsons will be getting a very nice surprise in the mail. Very nice, indeed.
I want the whole world to hear the story of my harrowing struggle with hypohemia.

Well, Countess Van Zeplin and I... What in blaze... Now you listen to me, you bargain basement Baudelaire. I'm not some dizzy starlet who can't string two words together. I can write this thing myself. You're fired.
"Chapter the Fifth... A Trip to the Infirmary, With Most Unexpected Results."
Oh, don't be frightened of this. It's nothing but a letter opener. Who are you?
Hello, there's more. "In case you can't tell, I'm being sarcastic..."
"...you stink, you are a senile, buck-toothed..." "...old mummy... with bony girl arms and you smell like an elephant's butt!"
I could crush him like an ant, but it would be too easy. No, revenge is a dish best served cold. I'll bide my time until... Oh, what the hell. I'll just crush him like an ant.
"Senile," eh? "Buck-toothed," am I? "Bony arms," are they? "Liver spots," did I? "Chinless," will you?
Now, that's odd. I've just robbed a man of his livelihood, and yet I feel strangely empty. Tell you what, Smithers. Have him beaten to a pulp.
In closing, gentle reader, I'd like to thank you. What's that you say? Me thanking you? No, it's not a misprint. For you see, I enjoyed writing this book as much as you enjoyed reading it. The end.
No need, Smithers. As usual, you've been the sober "ying" to my raging "yang." Put 'er there, old pal.
We'll get the Simpsons a present, an extravagant present! A mad, unthinkable, utterly impossible present! A frabulous, grabulous, zip-zoop-zabulous present!
A pool table? Are you mad? I'm not gonna turn his home into a saloon.
Don't you dare sully this moment with your price taggery! It's perfect!
Why, what did you think I was going to do -- have you beaten to a bloody pulp?
To show there's no hard feelings, please take an advance copy of my book, "Will There Ever Be A Rainbow?" And now, young fellow, I haven't forgotten you. Here.
Actually, son, it's a big, ugly Olmec Indian head. It was carved by Meso-American Indians over 3,000 years ago. This gruesome customer is Xt'tapalatakettle, the god of war.
Well, I'll let you get acquainted with SeÃ±or Xt'tapalatakettle. Ta!
Wait a minute, go back. Zoom in. Why is that man in pink?
Simpson, eh? Well, judging by his outlandish attire, he's some sort of free-thinking anarchist.
Spare me the tired semantics of the Simpson family! Take him away!
Or perhaps you two are in cahoots. Smithers, I seem to recall you had a penchant for bell-bottom trousers back in '79.
Oh, yes, of course. Your spirited hornpipe stole the show, as I recall. Now Doctor, what shall we do about our free wheeling fop over here?
Simpson, eh? How very strange. His job description clearly specifies an illiterate.
Ah! Look, Smithers, another member of our nuclear family, with some helpful suggestions. And what's your name?
Hm. "Keep that handsome owner out of sight. He's distracting the female employees." Smithers...
Oh! It's a real one! "No more apples in the vending machine, please." Well, that's almost a sentence!
Oh, of course. And don't worry, there'll be plenty of apples for you. Nobody will take away your precious apples.
Now, now, now. Tell my secretary I said you could have a free apple. She'll make everything all right, I promise.
Damned infernal gizmo. My kingdom for a left-handed can opener!
The world has turned has it not my tin-plated friend? Look at you -- you, who were once so proud -- Feel the wrath of the left hand of Burns!
The boys at the Diners Club will think I've gone quite mad. Oh, and I'll have that roadster in the corner as well.
Thank God we live in a country so hysterical over crime that a ten-year-old child can be tried as an adult.
Ah, Monday morning. Time to pay for your two days of debauchery, you hung-over drones.
Well, Smithers, don't you know how to paint the town red.

Well, a bit overly familiar, but I'll allow it. I took in a movie. An appalling little piece of filth. Its leading lady was a blonde harlot who spent half the film strolling around naked as a jaybird.
Just give the great unwashed a pair of oversized breasts and a happy ending, and they'll 'oink' for more every time.
Call me old-fashioned, but movies were sexier when the actors kept their clothes on. Vilma Banky could do more for me with one raised eyebrow than an entire...
Oh hello, Kent. Right now, skilled nuclear energy technicians are calmly correcting a minor, piffling malfunction.
But, I can assure you and the public that there is absolutely no danger whatsoever --
Oh, meltdown is one of those annoying buzzwords. I prefer to call it an unrequested fission surplus.
Oh, hot dog. Thank you for making my last few moments on earth socially awkward.
Oh, Smithers, I guess there's nothing left but to kiss my sorry butt good-bye!
Yes, we've isolated the problem and wouldn't you know? False alarm. It seems a single wayward crow flew into our warning system.
Excellent. Well, "ta". Hmmm, Smithers, I can still sell 'em snake oil. Now bring me a wine spritzer -- and don't be stingy with the vino.
So, Smithers, it seems you've underestimated one Homer Simpson... our next Employee-of-the-Month.
Smithers, you bean counter, give it up! Simpson's my man!
Now, now. That will do. Homer, for your bravery and skill, we award you this ham, this plaque, this discount coupon book, and my own personal thumbs up!
And to insure your immortality, your heroic visage will be added to our Wall of Fame... Oh, and uh, what's this? A congratulatory phone call from Earvin "Magic" Johnson.
Ah Simpson! There's someone I want you to meet. Aristotle Amadopolis, owner of the Shelbyville Nuclear Power facility.
It seems Ari's been having terrible worker problems at Shelbyville.
We want you to give them a pep talk that turns them from a bunch of donut-eating goof-offs into a pack of Homer Simpsons.
Oh cut the false modesty, it's getting tiresome. Besides, it's your duty. Employee of the Month isn't all ham and plaques.
Well! Smithers, how kind of you to pay us a visit.
Little do they realize their days of suckling at my teat are numbered.

You know Smithers, I've always despised the laziness of the common worker. Then I realized his spirit was willing, but the flesh was weak. So I replaced the flesh -- which is weak -- with steel, which is strong. Behold, the greatest breakthrough in labor relations since the cat o' nine tails.
Keep your pants on, Smithers. First, we need... The human brain.
I don't know. I feel like a kid in a candy store.
Hello! An open grave. Smithers, get him out quickly, the stench is overpowering.
No, I didn't. Who is it? Frankenstein? The Booger Man?
Damn it, Smithers. This isn't rocket science, it's brain surgery.
Look, Smithers, a twitch... it's moving. It's alive! Oh, that fellow at Radio Shack said I was mad... well who's mad now?!
It wasn't suppose to be this way. It was supposed to be a thing of beauty, not this abomination.
Oh Smithers, I was wrong to play god. Life is precious, not a thing to be toyed with. Now, take out that brain and flush it down the toilet.
Oh, Smithers, when you look at me with those puppy dog eyes... all right.
Oh you're right, Smithers. I guess I owe you a coke.
And as for you, you clinking, clattering, cacophony of colligenous cogs and camshafts, take that.
Every bone... shattered... organs... leaking vital fluids. Slight headache... loss of appetite. Smithers, I'm going to die.
Well, perhaps. Smithers go to my office. In the third drawer of my desk are surgical tools and some ether...
Perhaps you're wondering why you have two heads? Well my body was crushed so I had my head grafted on to or shall we say ample frame.
But Homer, tonight's our reception for Queen Beatrice of the Netherlands.
It's a hobby. I'm not in this for any personal gain, heavens no. By the way, are you acquainted with our state's stringent usury laws?
Silly me, I must have just made up a word that doesn't exist. Now, what is the purpose of this loan?
Isn't that cute? Smithers, he's planning on joining the horsey set. That is it, isn't it? You're not planning to eat it?
Oh Smithers, let's not be so cold. His spirit is my collateral. Just sign this form and the money will be yours.
Sorry, I was just, uh, thinking of something funny Smithers did today.
A lovely promise, but one beyond the powers of a mere shampoo.
Snappy, do you it's hard to imagine, but I was once a barefoot boy with cheek of tan. I dreamed of grand slam homeruns and wiping out nations with the stroke of a pen.
Is there? Controlled nuclear fission is a demanding mistress, Snappy.
Yes, yes, exactly! You know, maybe it's time I sold the old girl.
You'll see the Statue of Liberty wearing lederhosen before you see Germans running my plant!
So I can look Uncle Fritz square in the monocle and say nein.
Now, don't worry. I think you'll find that these two gentlemen are as American as apple pie! Hans and Fritz, well that's just John and Frank!
I wanted to give you something to remember me by. I know you've always had your eye on this photo of Elvis and me.
Yes, but I couldn't understand a word that man said. Misht Burnsh, dajna boo mafrn friszner... er hound-dog.
Well, first I'll get that new hip I've been hankering for. Then, who knows? Bee keeping, boxing, bache ball?... The world is my oyster, Smithers. Farewell!
Listen, Smithers, you caught me at a bad time but my folk guitar class has been canceled for tonight. Would you like to get together for a drink?
That's right... gather the nectar, my little drones, and make the honey. Honey for your children.
Just a second, Smithers. Let me introduce you to the gang. That's Buzz. That's Honey. And you see that queen over there? Her name is "Smithers."
Ah, the mirthless laugh of the damned. Hold your nose, Smithers, we're going in!
Watch me blend in. Barkeep, some cheap domestic beer for me and my "buddy" here.
What good is money if you can't inspire terror in your fellow man? I've got to get my plant back!
This is my offer. I think you'll find it's most unfair, but those are the breaks.
Ooh, the Germans are mad at me. I'm so scared. Ooh, the Germans.
Uh-oh, the Germans are comin' to get me. Oh, don't let the Germans come after me... Oh no, the Germans are coming after me. Oh, no, they're so big and strong...
You too. This is a place of business, not a Peewee flop house!
Restore my office. Cancel all repairs. And rehire that chap who sassed me in the bar.

Smithers. I keep my friends close and my enemies even closer. He'll slowly regain his confidence as the months and years drift by, blissfully unaware that the sword of Damocles is dangling just above his head.
And then one day... when he least expects it --
Ironic, isn't it. The hunter has become the hunted. Oh God, Smithers, I feel so alive.
Hold the phone, Smithers... I like your attitude. Feisty yet spineless.
I don't care. I haven't been this impressed since I first laid eyes on a young boot-lick named Waylon Smithers.
Did you hear that, Ari? My boys need only to thump your tub and the title is ours.
Oh, if we're going to bet, why don't we make it interesting?

Oh, did you say a million? I'm... I'm sorry, my mind was elsewhere. I thought you would start with a small amount, then we would bait each other and... well, you know how it goes. Yes... certainly, a million will be fine.
Smithers, I've been thinking. Is it wrong to cheat in order to win a million dollar bet?
Let me rephrase that. Is it wrong if I cheat in order to win a million dollar bet?
No, Smithers. I've decided to bring in a few ringers. Professional baseballers.
We'll give them token jobs at the plant and have them play on our softball team. Honus Wagner, Cap Anson, Mordecai "Three Finger" Brown...
Damnation! All right, find me some good players. Living players! Scour the professional ranks. The American League. The National League. The Negro Leagues.
And now I'd like to introduce the new members of our happy power plant family. Our new security guard... Roger Clemens...
Our new, well uh, we'll make up jobs for these fellows later... Please say hello to Steve Sax, Don Mattingly, Darryl Strawberry, Ozzie Smith, Mike Scioscia, and Jose Canseco.
Oh, by the way, you new fellows, there's a sign up sheet for the company softball team on the bulletin board over there. Eh, just in case you wish to play.
One more outburst like that and I'll send you back to the big leagues!

As your new manager, I want to say this up front. No one is assured a spot in the starting line-up. I don't care if your name is Steve Sax, Darryl Strawberry, or... Smithers, what's one of the bad players' names?
Secondly, instead of beer, from now on you will all be drinking this!
It's a brain and nerve tonic. Rich in proteids and electromagnetic juices. It promotes robust health. Of course, it has been known to cause gigantism, but only in rare cases. Try some.
Excellent. Now, let's begin our training, shall we? Smithers -- the medicine balls.
Oh, I don't know. Throw it on the pile, I suppose.
Put a lid on it, Simpson. There's no "I" in "team".
Tomorrow is the biggest day of your lives. The Shelbyville game. So lights out at seven-thirty and abstain from coffee, tea, and cola drinks. Make no mistake, they pack a wallop.
Yes. Now, before I post the starting line-up I want to assure those of you whose names are not on the list, that I'm very disappointed in you. Something was lacking, let's call it heart.

Smithers, there's no way I can lose this bet. Unless, of course, my nine all-stars fall victim to nine separate misfortunes and are unable to play tomorrow. But that will never happen. Three misfortunes, that's possible. Seven misfortunes, there's an outside chance. But nine misfortunes... I'd like to see that.
Mattingly, for the last time, get rid of those sideburns!
Smithers, it's almost game time. Where the devil are my ringers?
You, look what you've done! My starting pitcher thinks he's a chicken! Make no mistake, I'm going to report this to the American Hypnotical Association.
Oh well, I guess it's not your fault... you did a good job.
Mattingly, I thought I told you to trim those sideburns. Go home! You're off the team! For good!

All right, you rag-tag bunch of misfits. You hate me, and I hate you even more. But without my beloved ringers, you're all I've got. So I want you to remember some inspiring things that someone else may have told you in the course of your lives, and go out there and win!
The man who plays your position is still here. Hit the pine.
All right, Monty, it's up to you managerial skills. What to do. Smithers, massage my brain.
All right, tie game. Bottom of the ninth, two outs, bases loaded, Strawberry coming up...
Wait! You! Strawberry! Good effort today. Take a lap and hit the showers. I'm putting in a right-handed batter to hit for you.
Yes. You see, you're a left-hander. And so is the pitcher. If I send up a right-handed batter, it's called playing the percentages. It's what smart managers do to win ballgames.
You should be very proud of yourself. Sit down! Simpson! You're batting for Strawberry.
If I tug the bill of my cap like so...
However, I can take that off by dusting my hands thusly.
If I want you to bunt, I will touch my belt buckle not once, not twice, but thrice...
Smithers, it's almost game time. Where the devil are my ringers?
What makes a man endanger his job, and yes, even his life, by asking me for money?
Nonsense! Dogs are idiots. Think about it, Smithers. If I came into your house and started sniffing at your crotch and slobbering all over your face, what would you say?
Yes, well, it does sound like fun. I can't wait to start pawing through my garbage like some starving raccoon.
Release the hounds. Well, neighbor I see you've got your running shoes on. That's a good thing.
Ah yes, I'll never forget the day he bagged his first hippie. That young man didn't think it was too "groovy."
I'm looking for something in an attack dog. One who likes the sweet gamy tang of human flesh.
Why here's the fellow! Wiry... fast... firm proud buttocks. Reminds me of me.
Now! As an attack dog, you'll be expected to neutralize intruders.
If that were a real Girl Scout I'd have been bothered by now.
Now here's a film that will turn you into a vicious souless killer. Enjoy.

Before you begin, let me make one thing clear to you. I want your legal advice. I even pay for it. But to me you're all vipers. You live on personal injury. You live on divorces. You live on pain and misery...... but I'm rambling. Anybody want any coffee?
Want it black, don't you? Black like your heart! It's so hard for me to listen to you, I hate you all so much... I'm sorry. It's my problem. I'll deal with it. Please continue.
Oh, brilliant. A cash settlement. I could have figured that out, you button-down maggot.
Ah, Simpson, you big virile son-of-a- gun. How would you like a check for two-thousand dollars?

All right, well, it just explains that you've won -- yes, that's it -- won the first annual... uh... Montgomery Burns... uh... Award for... a-a-a Outstanding Achievement in...a-a th... th.. the field of... uh, Excellence!
Yess... that was Bonita De Wolf and the Springfield Nuclear Plant Soft Shoe Society.
And now to present the award, here's former heavyweight champion, Smokin' Joe Frazier.
Well, you'd be a welcome change of pace from the rest of these crude and uncouth sailors.
He's either a fifty foot prehistoric ape, or a tourist trap concocted by the ape island jaycees. Either way, we're going ashore.
Of course. We wouldn't think of going without the bait... uh, that is, the bait-thing beauty -- The bathing beauty. I covered that up pretty well.
Uh, he's saying, "We wouldn't dream of sacrificing the blue-haired woman!"
Smithers, this is a golden opportunity. If we get him alive we can put him on Broadway. Dead, we'll sell monkey stew to the Army!
Now, we don't want to kill him, shoot him around the groin and belly.
All right, you big ape, get a snootful of this gas bomb.
Nice work, Smithers. When we get back, I'm giving you a raise.
Well, the ape's going to stand around for three hours or so. Then we'll close with the ethnic comedy of Douggan an Dershowitz.
Ladies and gentlemen, in his native land he was a king. But he comes before you in chains, for your own amusement. Presenting Homer, the Eighth Wonder of the World!
I am dreading the reviews, I can tell you that.
No, but his career is. I remember when Al Jolson ran amok at the Winter Garden and climbed the Chrysler Building. After that, he couldn't get arrested in this town.
Tonight, we've all come to honor a close friend of ours...
A man who provided the Burns Corporation with forty-five years of faithful service, Mr. Jack Marley.
Oh, me, me, me "I need all the attention just because it's my party, eh!"
With the departure of Mr. Marley, there will now be an entry-level position open in Sector 7G. Now get out. The bar is closed.
That woman -- she's so captivating. Smithers, my heart's pounding like a jackhammer.
I must have her. Smithers, zoom in. Closer... Closer... closer, damn it!
No need for alarm. I just came to give you the orchids and fragrant bath oils I lavish upon all my employees.
It's working! It's working! And the healthy snacks are on their way.
Marge, I'm giving you a raise and a new office... right next to mine.
Don't worry Smithers, I'm putting you where the action is.
I dreamed about her again last night, Smithers. You know that dream where you're in bed and they fly in through the window?
Yes, well, Smithers, I want you to arrange a party for two at my estate. Marge, me, and do you think you could dig up Al Jolson?
Oh, that's right, he's dead. And rather pungent. The rest of that night is something I'd like to forget. All right, then. Bring me that crooner she likes so much... Tom Jones.
Actually, I was wondering if you were free for a little get-together tonight. Dinner, dancing and ... Mr. Tom Jones.
You... have a husband? Yes, I can picture him now... rugged good looks... sweater knotted about his shoulders... curly locks shining in the sun like spun gold...
You don't have to sue me to get my pants off.
Why, Marge, look at all those flies buzzing around your head -- you're a mess, woman .
Homer, I want you to show this woman the time of her life.

Look at that pig stuffing his face with donuts on my time. That's right, keep eating. Little do you know you're drawing ever closer to the poisoned donut. There is a poisoned one isn't there, Smithers?
Relax, Simpson. I just brought you in here for a friendly, "Hello."
But wait, perhaps I'm being too hasty. You are highly skilled... at goofing off!
Now don't worry, Homer. You're the kind of guy I could really dig. A grave for. Your indolence is inefficacious!
No, all those bald children are arousing suspicion -- to the park!
Oh, and uh, I'll take that statue of Justice too.
Hello. My name is Mr. Snrub, and I come from... eh, someplace far away. Yes, that will do. Anyway, I-I say we invest that money back in the nuclear plant.
Well let's look at the contract ourselves. Benefits... perks... a green cookie on St. Patrick's Day? Oh, it didn't used to be this way, Smithers. No, it didn't used to be this way at all...
If only we had listened to that boy, instead of walling him up in the abandoned coke oven. Well, I'm going to avenge my grandfather. We'll take on that greedy union and get back our...
Hmm, he's a worthy foe. Look at him, Smithers. Exercising away while the others are off at the candy machine.
We don't have to be adversaries, Homer. We both want a fair union contract.
I mean, if I should slip something into your pocket, what's the harm?
Ah, Homer! I hope Crusher and Low Blow didn't hurt you.
Oh yes, but the telephone is so impersonal. I prefer the hands-on touch you only get with hired goons.
This is a thousand monkeys working at a thousand typewriters. Soon they'll have written the greatest novel known to man.
Let's see. "It was the best of times. It was the blurst of times?" You stupid monkey!
Yes, I really should stop ending the tour with it.
Now, Homer, I know what you're thinking and I want to take the pressure off.
It doesn't take a whiz to see that you're looking out for number one. Well, listen to me and you'll make a big splash very soon.
Well, you've won this round Simpson, but I'll grind you into the earth like a bug!
Simpson, be a dear and rub my legs till the feeling comes back.
Smithers, get me some strike breakers like the kind they had in the 30's.
Oooo, look at him strutting around like he's cock of the walk. Well, let me tell you, Homer Simpson is cock of nothing. Why you and I can run this plant ourselves.
Yes, thank you, Kent. Fifteen minutes from now I will wreak a terrible vengeance on this city. No one will be spared. No one!

Look at them all, through the darkness I'm bringing. They're not sad at all, they're actually singing! They sing without juicers! They sing without blenders! They sing without flunjers, capdabblers and smendlers! Tell Simpson I'm ready to deal
All right! You can even have the dental plan!... On one condition. You must resign as head of the union.
Smithers, I'm beginning to think that Homer Simpson was not the brilliant tactician I thought he was.
This man is costing my health plan five thousand dollars a day. I demand that he die with dignity.
You have no idea, woman, what that man's put me through.
Smithers, this plague doesn't scare me. I've constructed a germ-free chamber for myself. Not a single microbe can get in or out.
Huh? What? How dare you disturb me during nap time!
There must be some mistake. We, uh, we make cookies here. Mr. Burns' old fashioned, good time, extra chewy...
The watchdog of public safety. Is there any lower form of life?
Yes, he's in Geneva, chairing a conference on Nuclear Fission. Yes, that should stick.
Oh, very well, it's time for your bribe. Now you can either have the washer and dryer where the lovely Smithers is standing...
Or you can trade it all in for what's in this box.
Is that so? Well I have the feeling you'll be "dropping" the charges...
Hello, Simpson. My lawyers and I were in the neighborhood and thought we'd stop by.
Remember, your job and the future of your family hinges on your successful completion of Nuclear Physics 101.
Oh, and one more thing. You must find the jade monkey before the next full moon.
Don't worry, Simpson, it just so happens I have a chair at Springfield University...
I see. Well, you know, fellas, I look at the admissions board a lot like a baseball team. You all like baseball, don't you?
Yes, well, to have a successful baseball club, you need teamwork. Not some hot dog admissions officer playing by his own rules.
Smithers, dismember the corpse and send his widow a corsage.
Bobo! Bo-Bo! Oh, it's you. The bedpan's under my pillow.
Bobo? I meant Lobo. Sheriff Lobo. They never should have canceled that show.
That man who's getting all those laughs, Smithers. Who is he?
I want this Simpson fellow to perform comedy at my party. I must harness his fractured take on modern life.
Liar! I'll give you the thrashing of a lifetime! Resistance is futile. Oh God, how I only want my bear. But he's gone. Gone forever. I'd give anything to know what happened to him.
Bobo! My beautiful Bobo! I promise I'll never leave you behind again.
Ah, yes. Naturally I can't pay you much of a reward because... I'm strapped for cash.
As you can see, this old place is falling apart. But I'm sure we can come to an understanding.
Don't worry, Smithers, he's playing hard ball now. But it won't take him long to crack.
Excellent shot, Smithers. I'll be squeezing my Bobo in no time.
As you can see, Simpson, I've taken over all seventy-eight channels. And you won't see any of your favorite shows again until you give in.
What's that you say? You can live without television as long as you have beer?

Wrong. All beer trucks heading towards Springfield have been diverted. This town will be as dry as a bone. And if the rest of you beer swilling tube jockeys out there have a problem with this, talk to Homer Simpson.
Well, Maggie, I've given this a lot of thought. I'm sure we can come to some sort of agreement.
Okay, Maggie, you win. But I want you to do something for me. Hang on to that bear. Don't make the same mistake I made.
For me? Bobo? Smithers, I'm so happy. Something amazing has happened. I'm actually happy. Take a note. From now on, I'm only going to be good and kind to everyone.
Ah, Bobo reunited at last. But I can't help but wonder what the future holds for you. Ah, yes. Wonder...
Bobo I know I say this every century, but I'll never leave you behind again.
Hmm... Who's that goat-legged fellow? I like the cut of his jib.
Welcome, come in. Ah, fresh victims for my ever-growing army of the undead.
Ooh sounds delish. Let me just toss some jeans on and... Wait a minute! Who is this?!
I feel like such a free spirit. And I'm really enjoying this so-called "iced cream."
Why that's a fabulous idea. Anything else you'd like? How about real lead in the radiation shields? Urinal cakes maybe? Smithers, throw this at him.
Yes, well, find someone cheap. It's been a very lean year for us.
Excellent, Zutroy. Work hard and each day you'll get a shiny penny.
That's preposterous. Zutroy here is as American as apple pie.
All right, I'll bring in a woman. But I still stand by my hiring policies.
Look at those two inseparable chums, Smithers. That's exactly the teamwork we'd like to showcase at this year's Energy Convention.
Well no one else seems to share the same spirit of camaraderie.
Thank you so much for visiting our plant, Dr. Kissinger.
Hey, tough times, eh? I've lived through twelve recessions, eight panics, and five years of McKinley-nomics. I'll survive this!
Oh! Very well -- lay off... Him, him, him, him...
Hmm, better keep the egghead. He just might come in handy.
By building a casino, I could tighten my stranglehold on this dismal town!
Oh, I'll never forget my carefree boyhood days on this old boardwalk...
What was I laughing at, now? Oh yes, that crippled Irishman.
Idiots. I'll design it myself. I know what people like. It's got to have sex appeal, and a catchy name.
Well, I've discovered the perfect business. People swarm in, empty their pockets, and scuttle off. Nothing can stop me now. Except microscopic germs. But we won't let that happen. Will we Smithers?
Smithers, I've designed a new plane. I call it the Spruce Moose, and it will carry two hundred passengers from New York's Idlewild Airport to the Belgian Congo in seventeen minutes.

I was hoping I wouldn't have to tell you this, but... I'm afraid your family doesn't want you back.

She said "no" to me. Do you know how many women have said "no" to me? One hundred thirty. But only one since I've become a billionaire. And she's the one for me. I'm in love!
Whooop de-doo, Mr. Florist! Whoop de-doo, Mr. Physical Trainer! Whoop-de-doo, Mr. President!

Why it's Fred Flintstone and his lovely wife, Wilma! Oh, and this must be little Pebbles! Mind if I come in? I brought chocolates.
Now, my dear, if you look in your champagne, I think you'll find a little surprise...
Not to worry. I believe there's another one around here, somewhere.

The ring, you little imbecile! Before I really lose my temper!

I should be resisting this, but I'm paralyzed with rage... and island rhythms.

Ah yes, the special demotivational plaque, to break what's left of your spirit. Because, you see, you're here forever.

But I like that film biography idea. A slick Hollywood picture to gloss over my evil rise to power, like "Bugsy," or "Working Girl." Get me Steven Spielberg!

I've got to win this one. I've bribed everyone in Hollywood.
...and I know the little fellas would love romping around my many acres, chasing my many cars, drinking from my many toilets...
Hmm? Oh, of course not. They're your pets, you can do as you wish. Good day, everyone.
There you are, there ya go li'l' fella, and you...
Smithers, look! He's standing up! I've never seen anything so adorable. You know who it reminds me of...

Ahoy there, Dean! I understand you're taking suggestions from students, eh? Well, me and my Fourth Form chums think it would be quite "corking" if you'd sign over your oil well to the local energy concern!
I want that oil well! I've got a monopoly to maintain! I own the Electric Company and the Waterworks, plus the hotel on Baltic Avenue.
I must have that oil! Oogh! Smithers! Smithers, help me subdue this beast!
That's it. Frimble about with your widgets and doobobs. It'll all be a monument to futility when my plan comes to fruition.

Hmm, yes. I believe that's little Maggie Simpson -- the baby who found my precious teddy-bear Bobo. Oh and there's that, ah Simpson mutt, my former guard dog.

Dispose of it. And uh, send a thank-you note to Marge, Bart, Lisa, and Maggie Simpson.
Ah. Soon that mighty apparatus will burst forth with its precious fluid. Almost sexual, isn't it, Smithers?
No, not while my greatest nemesis still provides our customers with free light, heat, and energy. I call this enemy... the sun!

I will not suffer your insubordination! There has been a shocking decline in the quality and quantity of your toadying, Waylon, and you will fall into line. Now.
Take that, bowl-a-rama! Take that, convenience mart! Take that, nuclear power pla-- Oh, fiddlesticks.
What? What are you talking about? Clearly make sense, man. I can't understand a word you're saying. You're just babbling incoherently like some sort of...
Oh, those wheels are squeaking a bit. Perhaps I could sell him a little oil.
I've decided to protect myself... Ever since I was attacked in my office by an unidentified assailant.
Oh, you all talk big, but who here has the guts to stop me?
Mmm hmm. Very well. One last question: Have you ever seen the sun set at 3:00 PM?
Shut up, you! Take one last look at the sun, Springfield.
Ahhh. Perpetual twilight bathed in the glow of Burns brand electricity!
Hello lamp post/ Whatcha knowin'? / I've come to watch your power flowing.
After all these years, things are finally starting to go my way. I feel like celebrating. I...
Oh, it's you. What are you so happy about? I see. Well, I think you'd better drop it. I said drop it! Get your -- get your hands off--
Smithers, wait your turn. There's plenty of hot water for all.
That's right. The year is 1965, and you and I are undercover detectives on the hot-rod circuit. Now let's burn rubber, baby!
Pish-posh. It will be like taking candy from a baby.
Mersimp... Son... what is the... mer... meaning of this? Smithers, who is this beast that's shaking me?
Shot? By you? I'm afraid not my primitive friend. Your kind has neither the cranial capacity nor the opposable digits to operate a firearm. The one who shot me was...
With the sun blocker in place and the town aghast, I was on top of the world...
So I wanted to kick up my heels and indulge my sweet tooth.
Yes... that's the one. Smithers had thwarted my attempt to take candy from a baby, but with him out of the picture, I was free to wallow in my own crapulance.
But the old exhume was misleading. Taking the candy proved exceedingly difficult.
But finding only slacked jawed gawkers, I gave up and collapsed on the sundial.
What? No! With my last ounce of strength I sucked out my gold fillings and swallowed them. Those paramedics have sticky fingers.
You know, Smithers, I think I'll donate a million dollars to the local orphanage... when pigs fly!
Raise your right hock. Aerate! Raise your left hock. Aerate! I want to see more Teddy Roosevelts and less Franklin Roosevelts!
I am pleased to dedicate this remote work terminal. It will allow our safety inspector here to perform his duties from home. And so, excelsior to you, Mr. What's the name of this gastropod?
Workers, please! There'll be time for the frozen pudding wagon later! You still owe me ten more Iroquois twists!
Homer, your bravery and quick thinking have turned a potential Chernobyl into a mere Three-Mile Island. Bravo!
We'll have you out of there as soon as our tech boys get you decontaminated.
Now Homer, if there's anything else I can do for you, please don't hesitate to ask.
Here's your caption, boys: "Local Hero shuns spotlight and pitches in!"
Their flower power is no match for my glower power.
My germs! My precious germs! They never harmed a soul! They never even had a chance! Whoever did this will never get past me!
You just made a very big mistake. You'll spend the rest of your life in pris--
Yes, I'd like to send this letter to the Prussian consulate in Siam by aero-mail. Am I too late for the 4:30 auto-gyro?
Wait a minute, I know that woman. But from when and in what capacity?
She has the sloping brow and cranial bumpage of the career criminal.
Well, that "nice lady" set the cause of biological warfare back thirty years.
Look, we know you bought the tombstone. We know the fugitive visited that tombstone. Whose tombstone was it?!
Nonsense! Dogs are idiots. Think about it, Smithers. If I came into your house and started sniffing at your crotch and slobbering all over your face, what would you say?
I dreamed about her again last night, Smithers. You know that dream where you're in bed and they fly in through the window?
With the sun blocker in place and the town aghast, I was on top of the world...
So I wanted to kick up my heels and indulge my sweet tooth.

Or so I thought. At the last moment, Smithers, drunk as a lemur, lurched out of the darkness and fired.
But finding only slack-jawed gawkers, I gave up and collapsed on the sundial.
Not exactly. Smithers, for attempting to kill me, I'm giving you a five percent pay cut.
Oooo... I need some more ether. I can still feel the movement of the emery board.
Pop 'n Fresh! You glutinous little doughboy! Oh, there's something I've wanted to do to you for years.
Oh, why, certainly, Pop 'n Fresh. I... I owe my robust physique to your tubes of triple-bleached goo.
Why, it's that delightful TV leprechaun! I'm going to get your lucky charms.
Stop everything! I don't remember writing a check for bowling!
Yes, that was unpleasant for all concerned. Anyway, back to the checks... Stop everything! I don't remember writing a check for bowling!
Simpson, eh? Let's shut down this bowling scam right now.
I've had one of my unpredictable changes of heart. Seeing these fine young athletes reveling in the humiliation of a vanquished foe... I haven't felt this energized since my last... boweling.

Smithers, I'm afraid I won't be able to play tonight. My old gimpy knee has gone akimbo again, and...

Oh. I'm afraid I've had one of my trademark changes of heart. You see, teamwork will only take you so far, then the truly evolved person makes that extra grab for personal glory. You there -- fill it up with petroleum distillate and re-vulcanize my tyres! Post haste!
Well, he's certainly got a loose waggle. Perhaps I've finally found a golfer worthy of a match with Monty Burns, eh?
Oh, he just looked so forlorn, Smithers, with his "Oh, I can't go to prison, Monty! They'll eat me alive!"

Rant on, Simpson, but your vainglorious boasting will only add savor to my inevitable triumph.
Oh, quit cogitating, Steinmetz, and use an open-faced club! The sand wedge!

Cheating for me? Good lord, Smithers, that's patently unnecessary. I'm one of the world's finest golfers! In all the years you've caddied for me, I've never lost a-- Oh.

Ahoy-hoy? No, you have the wrong number. This is 5-2-4-6. I suspect you need more practice working your telephone machine. Not at all. Ahoy.

Ah, and my dear, dear Smithers... you're no longer needed at all. You're fired. Ta!

I don't need you to do any of this. I'm totally self-sufficient now. What I would like, though, is a Spanish peanut.
It's a remarkable thing. In the short time you were gone, I learned to be completely self reli--

"Dead -- tired," but I'm quite refreshed now, thank you.
Leave them for whom? The Germans? The folks who shoot at us all day? Let's just take them. We'll all be rich! Rich as Nazis!
Then it's agreed. Of course, we can't sell the paintings now. We'd be caught. How many of you are familiar with the concept of a "tontine?"

Ah, Larry, my lad, I've gone over this story in my mind a million times. It was 1941 -- the -- no, '39 -- my 25th Yale reunion...

Who should appear but the unrequited love of my college years, Mimsy Bancroft...Of course, by then Mimsy had her share of wrinkles and a gray hair or two, but my adoring eyes saw past those minor imperfections to her 21-year-old daughter, Lily.

Ah. Excellent. This is exactly the kind of trickery I'm paying you for. But, but how do we turn your average Joe Sixpack against Mary Bailey?
-- by the time this paid political announcement is done, every Johnny Lunchpail in this whole stupid state will be eating out of my hand.
Oh, hello friends. I'm Montgomery Burns, your next governor, and I'm here to talk to you about my little friend, here. Blinky.
Many of you consider him to be a hideous genetic mutation. Nothing could be further from the truth. But don't take my word for it. Let's ask an actor portraying Charles Darwin what he thinks.
Oh hello, Charles. Be a good fellow and tell our viewers about your theory of natural selection.
So... you're saying this fish might have an advantage over other fish. It may, in fact, be a kind of super fish!

No. You see, friends... if our anti-nuclear naysayers and choose-up-siders were to come upon an elephant frolicking in the waters next to our nuclear power plant, they'd probably blame his ridiculous nose on the nuclear bogeyman.

The truth is this fish is a miracle of nature with a taste that can't be beat. Mmmm mmmm. So, to summarize: Say what you want about me. I can take the slings and arrows. But stop slandering poor, defenseless Blinky. Good night and God bless.
We're gonna send - a message - to those bureaucrats - down there in the State Capital!
Oh. I get your angle. Every Joe Meatball and Sally Housecoat in this God-forsaken state will see me hunkering down for chow with Eddie Punchclock. The media will have a field day!
Only an innocent child could get away with such blasphemy. God bless them all. Amen.
Hello, Homer. Marge, you look dazzling. Oh, and look, I've brought noodle kugel.
Oh, of course. A little roughhousing with the pets is good for a man's appetite.
Goodness! I didn't realize this casual dinner was going to turn into a charged political debate.
Homer, I agree with you and, if I'm elected governor , I will lower taxes whether those bureaucrats in the State capital like it or not.
Lisa, do you have a question you would like to ask your Uncle Montgomery?

Oooh, a tough question, but a fair one. Lisa, there's no single answer. Some voters respond to my integrity. Others are more impressed with my incorruptibility... still others by my determination to lower taxes, and the bureaucrats in the state capital can put that in their pipes and smoke it.
...some can't even get a fair shake, or even a square deal... Ummmm, smells delightful.
You must have a few tricks left up your sleeves. Smithers, boil some coffee. We're not licked yet.
Wait! Come back! You can't do this to me! I'm Charles Montgomery Burns!
She's right. Take me home, Smithers. We'll destroy something tasteful.
Ironic, isn't it Smithers? This anonymous clan of slack-jawed troglodytes has cost me the election, and yet if I were to have them killed, I would be the one to go to jail. That's democracy for you.
Simpson, I shall make it the focus of my remaining years that your dreams will go unfulfilled.
Well, take your mind off contaminates for one night and have a hot dog.
Huh? Hmmm, oh, oh yes... Homer and Marge Simpson. Oh, and these must be Bart, Lisa and uh, "Expecting".

Heh, heh. As well they might. You know, Smithers, when I was a young buck, my patented fadeaway pitch was compared by many to the "trouble ball" of the late great Satchel Paige. Spit on this for me, Smithers.
Ah, sitting with the employees. I guess this proves I'm their friend. You did get me something on an aisle, Smithers? I don't want to be surrounded by them.
Actually, I was wondering if you'd join me. My treat.
Oh well, I used to rile the late, great Connie Mack with that one at old Shibe Park.
Hmmm. Crude, but I like it. What do you say we freshen up our little drinkie poos?
My one game of the year... ruined by pathetic incompetence.
Yes. Unfortunately, Homer Simpson's shameless display of exhibitionism tainted the entire evening. I want him banned for life from all company outings.
Mmmm, delicious. Smithers, every year you outstrip yourself in succulence.
Oh, no! I couldn't eat another bite. Dispose of all this. I did, however, save room for your special pumpkin pie.
Oh, for crying out loud... Just give him a nickel and let's get going.
Yes. My attorneys have advised me to pay you for running over your child. So I'm cutting you a check.
... One... Hundred... Dollars! Of course you'll have to sign a waiver, relinquishing your right to sue and so forth... merely a formality...

Oh, so extortion is the name of your little game, is it Simpson? Very well. Then you get nothing. I have the finest lawyers in Springfield, Simpson. Tangle with me and I'll crush you like a paper cup.
A million dollars! Smithers! I want this Homer J. Simpson fired!

Well... all right, then. I don't want to seem like an ogre. I'll bide my time. Let him twist in the wind... slowly... slowly. And then... when the papers have found their new "flavor of the month", he'll find out this cat has claws!
I should be able to run over as many kids as I want!

Suddenly, that incorrigible Simpson boy, darted in front of me...

...and that ugly customer was the last Indonesian Rhino on earth.
Oh, I don't like everything about them, just their heads. Well, would you care for some wine, old buddy?
Bottoms up Simpson, there's plenty more where that came from.

Well, a handsome sum that can end this little embrolio once and for all.
Up-up-up-up. Don't answer me now. Relax, talk it over with the missus, soak in the opulence of your surroundings and dream of what might be. Smithers, let's go powder my nose.
Sorry, offer's expired. I guess we'll just have to let the jury decide, twelve good men and true. Good day. Smithers, release the hounds.

Excellent. I'm so keen on seeing Watson vs. Tatum II, I'd even go to an employee's house. Oh, I can picture it now. The screen door rusting off its filthy hinges. Mangy dog staggering about looking vainly for a place to die.
We were just in the neighborhood and thought we'd drop by.
The fight? Don't mind if I do. Oh, Simpson. Good news -- I brought some munchies. Smithers -- the Cheetos.

Oh, hogwash! Why, I once watched Gentleman Jim Corbett fight an Eskimo fellow bare-knuckled for a hundred and thirteen rounds. Back then, of course, if a fight lasted less than fifty rounds, we demanded our nickel back.
Mr. Simpson, I dread the day when a hundred thousand dollars isn't worth groveling for.

Damnation, Smithers! This idea of yours to immortalize me in a portrait was as half-baked as your idea about me having children!
Excellent. Once again the wheel has turned and Dame Fortune has hugged Montgomery Burns to her sweet perfumed bosom. Somebody up there likes me, Smithers.

Beatles, eh? Oh, yes. I seem to remember their off-key caterwauling on the old Sullivan show. What was he thinking? Mrs. Simpson, this commission and all its glory can be yours, but first you must look me straight in the eye and answer one simple question.
Yes, yes, yes! Now don't be stingy with the blush, Smithers.
Well, aieeee! There's something on my leg! Get it off! Get it off!
If you'll excuse me, I'm changing for a board meeting.
We've only got two days left, so I'd advise you to shut up and paint!
Let me get this straight. You're pleased with your current appearance? Ah, why my good man, you're the fattest thing I've ever seen. And I've been on safari.
Thank goodness. Another day in this suburban nightmare and I would've needed half a white valium. Thank you for your gracious hospitality. See you at the unveiling.
Friends, art lovers, security personnel. Today is a red letter day for the Springfield Palace of Fine Art. A new wing for our museum and a portrait commemorating the man who ponied up the dough.
Ladies and gentlemen, may I invite you to behold... Montgomery Burns!
You know, I'm no art critic, but I know what I hate. And I don't hate this. Your painting is bold but beautiful. And uh, incidentally, thanks for not making fun of my genitalia.
